utterances: And congratulations to Governor Huckabee for winning the gold.
Nice job.
But you know, just as Dan Jansen pointed out, you win the silver in one event, it doesn't mean you're not going to come back and win the gold in the final event.
And that we're going to do.
(Soundbite of applause)

The Republican race now moves to New Hampshire, where Huckabee has next to no organization, but where Romney faces a strong challenge from John McCain, who tied for third place in Iowa with Fred Thompson.
Ron Paul finished fifth and Rudy Giuliani sixth.
McCain, speaking in New Hampshire, clearly relished Romney's setback.
I consider it to be Governor Huckabee's victory.
I think he earned it.
I think he worked hard and I think it's his victory, and I congratulate him, especially the fact that he ran largely a positive campaign.
And I guess that that should be, I think, a lesson to all of us.
NPR congressional correspondent Scott Detrow has been covering the funeral and joins us in the studio.
That's NPR's Mara Liasson reporting from Iowa.
And Mara, we've been talking with a couple of Iowa caucus-goers overnight who said their rooms were quite crowded last night.
There's no doubt about it, turnout was the big story here; 239,000 Democrats came out last night.
That's up from 124,000 in 2004, almost double the turnout.
Republicans - also turnout was up, 112,000 turned last night.
That's up from 87,000 caucus-goers in 2000, which is the last time there was a contested Republican race here.
Democrats, though, clearly had the energy, much bigger crowds.
Every one of the leading Democratic candidates had a great organization and they got out every single last available voter.
Well, they certainly got out more people than normal, although I do have to mention it's still a relatively small percentage of the possible voters in a relatively small state.
That's true.
But the reason why turnout is so important is because it means that Democrats are energized.
They're excited.
This is not a good sign for Republicans for November.
Well, now, what are the signs here for New Hampshire then?
What is the spillover effect, if any, to the next state up?
Well, traditionally New Hampshire sometimes validates the Iowa results.
Sometimes it ignores them.
But remember, last time, 2004, John Kerry started caucus night in Iowa about seven or eight points down in New Hampshire.
He won.
Immediately he was seven or eight points up.
There are only four days between now and the New Hampshire primary.
There's not a whole lot of time to turn things around between now and January 8th.

On the Republican side, the New Hampshire primary is going to be a very different story than the Iowa caucuses - very different kind of Republican electorate, much fewer evangelical voters, immigration not as important an issue.
So I think Huckabee will find the political terrain there quite different.

Does Huckabee have a problem, though, because he's finally broken through, he's finally won here, but he's only got a few days to try to capitalize on that and build more support elsewhere in the country?
That's part of the problem.
One of the other problems is it's not a lot of time for him to raise money.
He's got New Hampshire in four days, then he'll probably turn his attention to South Carolina, and then at least the calendar slows down a little bit.
And if he keeps on winning, he'd have a chance to build on the momentum.
Did anything surprise you in the results from last night, Mara?
A lot of things surprised me.
The fact that Obama did better than Clinton among women, the fact that Huckabee did well among almost all groups of Republicans.
He didn't just win with the support of evangelicals.
He got the support of mainstream Republicans too.
The fact that Clinton only won with those very older voters, over 65.
You know, I thought it was just a stunning result all around.
NPR national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
Thanks very much.
Thank you, Steve.
Unidentified Man #1: I believe in the power of love.
Unidentified Man #2: I believe that a generation of young people...
Unidentified Woman #1: I believe it deeply and sincerely.
Unidentified Man #3: I believe in the importance of passing this knowledge on.
Unidentified Woman #2: I believe that everyone wants to love and be loved.
Unidentified Man #4: All of these add up to my belief in the dignity of the individual.
Unidentified Man #5: I believe in people.
Unidentified Man #6: This I believe.
Our series, This I Believe, allows people to share the principles that guide their daily lives.
Today, we hear from Dr. Anthony Fauci.
He oversees the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and he's one of the country's best-known authorities on AIDS and HIV.
Here's our series curator, independent producer Jay Allison.
Dr.
Fauci's career had humble beginnings.
He grew up in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and delivered prescriptions by bicycle for his father's drugstore.
Now, and for over 20 years, even as he guides research and US policy on AIDS and bioterrorism, he continues to see patients.
He considers himself a driven man.
His belief is in both the fuel and the purpose of the drive.
Here is Dr. Anthony Fauci with his essay for This I Believe.
I believe I have a personal responsibility to make a positive impact on society.
I've tried to accomplish this goal by choosing a life of public service.
I'm a physician and a scientist confronting the challenge of infectious diseases.
I consider my job a gift.
It allows me to try and help alleviate the suffering of humankind.
I have three guiding principles that anchor my life, and I think about them every day.
First, I have an unquenchable thirst for knowledge.

Knowledge goes hand-in-hand with truth, something I learned with a bit of tough love from my Jesuit education, first at Regis High School in New York City and then at Holy Cross College in Worcester, Massachusetts.
I consider myself a perpetual student.
You seek and learn every day; from an experiment in the lab, from reading a scientific journal, from taking care of a patient.
Because of this, I rarely get bored.
Second, I believe in striving for excellence.
I sweat the big and the small stuff.
I do not apologize for this.
One of the byproducts of being a perfectionist and constantly trying to improve myself are sobering feelings of low-grade anxiety and a nagging sense of inadequacy.
But this not anxiety without a purpose; no, this anxiety keeps me humble.
It creates a healthy tension that serves as the catalyst that drives me to fulfill my limited potential.
This has made me a better physician and scientist.
Without this tension, I wouldn't be as focused.
I have accepted that I will never know or understand as much as I want.
This is what keeps the quest for knowledge exciting, and it is one of the reasons I would do my job even if I did not get paid to come to work every day.
I'd say, absolutely.
North Korea is a brutally poor state.
It has really no kind of exports to speak of, other than counterfeit dollars and missile technology.
So he can't pacify the population with goodies.
So he's had to compensate for that by being, you know, incredibly ruthless, but also incredibly wily.
He says the FARC has camps and cocaine-producing labs in Ecuador.
He also says the FARC makes cocaine deals in Ecuador with traffickers, including chieftains from Mexican cartels.
The Colombian vice minister for defense is Sergio Jaramillo.
He says lax controls in other countries permit the FARC to thrive.
That means that the FARC fronts that are on the border areas have become the cash cows of the FARC.
In the past, the FARC's chief aim was taking power in Colombia.
(Soundbite of gunfire)
In a video taken by the FARC in the late 1990s, they overwhelmed the government's security forces in a daylight raid.
Back then, the FARC, which stands for Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, operated like a conventional army.
That threat triggered American aid to fight the FARC.
FARC leader Manuel Marulanda laid out the group's objectives in a rare interview conducted a generation ago and shown in a recent documentary.
(Soundbite of documentary)
(Foreign language spoken)
He said the FARC wanted to redistribute land, and that the FARC would achieve its goal through the arms struggle.
FARC folk songs spoke of fighting for a better world.
(Soundbite of music)
Unidentified Man #2: (Singing foreign language)
Today, Marulanda is dead, and no one talks of land reform.
Instead, officials say the FARC focuses on drugs while launching hit-and-run attacks.
But under a long, withering army offensive, the FARC is falling back.
Mark Chernick is a professor at Georgetown University who's written extensively on the FARC.
We're very clearly seeing that they're being pushed over the border, and they are now strategically retreating on the other sides of the borders.
Ecuadorian officials do not deny that the rebels cross into Ecuador, nor that the group traffics drugs.
But they blame Colombia for not controlling its side of the border, and they say the Colombians exaggerate claims of corruption among Ecuadorian authorities.
Miguel Carvajal is the minister of internal and external security.
(Foreign language spoken)
Caravajal says he doesn't believe as much cocaine moves through Ecuador as the Colombians claim.
He also says his country is a leader in the fight against the drug trade.
Still, Ecuador's police recently charged a senior government official in a drug-trafficking case, a case involving the FARC.
Carvajal dismissed the episode as isolated.
